programme.title: Earth Odyssey With Dylan Dreyer
programme.desc: Today on Earth Odyssey, host Dylan Dreyer takes us to the peak of South America to the Andes Mountains. The tumultuous weather and treacherous heights have caused many unusual animals to form specialized behaviors in order to survive. We'll explore what life is like for the descendants of the Incas, as well as the animals that call the Andes Mountains home. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Earth Odyssey With Dylan Dreyer
programme.desc: Today on Earth Odyssey, host Dylan Dreyer takes us back to the Philippines where we will find some of the most fascinating wildlife in the animal kingdom. We'll head to the mangrove forests, where people still call home and use the rivers and streams as a means of transportation, food and fun. We will also head to the trees where macaques play and where tree nymphs turn into beautiful butterflies. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: The Young and the Restless *
programme.desc: An iconic, enduring soap opera, this is the steamer set in Genoa City, where the Newman and Abbott dynasties stir it up in the bedroom and the boardroom. Best known for long-term love triangles, issue-oriented plots, a multi-ethnic cast and slick production values, `Y&R' has been showered with Emmys, launched countless careers and spawned the equally lavish `The Bold and the Beautiful.' Former cast members include Tom Selleck and David Hasselhoff. (cc).(n)

programme.title: The Bold and the Beautiful *
programme.desc: The high-glam soap about L.A.'s fashionable and fertile Forrester clan was designed as a sister soap to the popular 'The Young and the Restless,' and quickly won ratings and global fans with cast crossovers, exotic remotes, glossy runway shows and fast-paced storylines about beautiful people behaving badly. In 2004, the show introduced a new family, the Marones, and recruited several nighttime alums to beef up the cast. And to create a little chaos. (cc).(n)

programme.title: The Talk
programme.desc: A weekday gabfest offering a female perspective on the day's headlines and other trending topics, including family, pop culture and health. Celebrity guests are interviewed and music artists perform. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Dr. Phil
programme.desc: The life strategist offers advice on a wide range of topics, including marital, financial and self-image issues. Phil McGraw began his own show after he became a popular recurring guest on `The Oprah Winfrey Show.' (cc).(n)

programme.desc: A woman from Slovakia sues small business owners for allegedly scamming her on her Visa application; A dog breeder sues a man for defamation after he claims that he did not receive the puppy he paid for. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Let's Make a Deal
programme.desc: Costumed contestants compete for the chance to win and trade prizes. Taped in Orlando at the Disney/MGM Studios Theme Park.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Family Feud
programme.desc: Two families of five try to guess what the 'survey said' in polls conducted with 100 people in this durable game show. Ray Combs took over as the host of this version from 1988-94, and original emcee Richard Dawson returned for one season in 1994. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled `Password Plus' and `Super Password.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled `Password Plus' and `Super Password.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.desc: Costumed contestants compete for the chance to win and trade prizes. Taped in Orlando at the Disney/MGM Studios Theme Park.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Family Feud

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled `Password Plus' and `Super Password.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: House battles to save the life of a volatile death-row inmate (LL Cool J) who collapses in an exercise yard after hearing the "voices" of the four people he murdered. Just getting him to the hospital requires legal gymnastics, and recently rehired hospital lawyer Stacy Warner (Sela Ward) performs them---without Cuddy's knowledge. Meanwhile, Cameron refuses to believe a young woman's lung-cancer diagnosis. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A child cancer patient (Sasha Pieterse) hallucinates for no apparent reason, and bravely undergoes numerous procedures to determine the cause---too bravely, House suspects. He thinks her bravery could be a symptom of a brain tumor. Meanwhile, in the clinic, House must deal with a young man who unsuccessfully tried to alter his appearance. Elvis Costello covers Christina Aguilera's "Beautiful" for the show. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A young handyman (Ignacio Serricchio) working for Cuddy falls from her roof, and his condition worsens in the hospital. Meanwhile, a black clinic patient complains of racism when Foreman gives him a blood-pressure medication targeted to blacks. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A doctor (Ron Livingston) who's famous for his humanitarian work in Africa collapses while giving a presentation in a drug-company boardroom. Meanwhile, an imperious clinic patient doesn't like Foreman's bedside manner and complains to Cuddy about it. Trouble is, Foreman was wearing House's name tag at the time. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House

programme.title: ER

programme.title: ER

programme.title: ER
programme.desc: Greene (Anthony Edwards) must tend to a wounded gunman who was shot by police after wiring dynamite to his body and taking hostages; Weaver is upset by Ross's surprising news; Carter becomes involved with a patient. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: ER

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A pregnant 42-year-old celebrity photographer (Anne Ramsay) suffers a stroke while shooting a rock star (All-American Rejects' Tyson Ritter), and soon her kidneys and liver begin to fail as well. programme.title: House
programme.desc: House and Cuddy have an airborne medical crisis while returning from a symposium in Singapore. It begins when a first-class passenger becomes violently ill. House suspects meningitis, and soon others become sick, Cuddy among them. Back at the hospital, Chase, Cameron, Foreman and Wilson struggle to determine what's killing a 58-year-old woman who collapsed just before having sex with a high-end prostitute. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 6-year-old girl collapses with pericarditis, then has a stroke. This shouldn't be happening to someone so young. But then Chase and Cameron find a bloody T-shirt in a vent in her bedroom. Meanwhile, her 8-year-old brother develops a crush on Cameron, who has been bickering with Chase since she broke off their affair. And House gives Wilson a pair of theater tickets, then becomes jealous when he goes to the play with Cuddy, but House shows it in an unexpected way. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: All the doctors try to find what's wrong with a 28-year-old con artist who collapses after her brain “freezes,” but the case becomes personal for Foreman. Dutton and Beverly Todd) arrive unexpectedly; House plays mind games with one of Wilson's ex-wives (Jane Adams); and Wilson and Cuddy go on another date. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 14-year-old with leukemia needs a bone-marrow transplant from his 10-year-old brother to save his life, but the brother develops an infection that not only prevents him from donating but could kill him as well. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: House
programme.desc: A 19-year-old (Lyndsy Fonseca) coughs up blood and her condition soon deteriorates. programme.title: House
